questions.question_text:
The documents from a workgroup laser printer are not printing correctly. Some of the print is missing, and the pages come out dusty.
Which of the following should a technician do to fix this issue?

discussion.content:
For me, by process of elimination D. would make the most logical answer.
B is on top of the printer the scans not prints
C is a circuit board
A is really irrelevant

questions.question_text: Which of the following IP addressing types is MOST likely to use an IP address starting with 169.254?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The Official CompTIA® A+® Core 1 and Core 2 Student Guide (Exams 220-1001 and 220-1002) | 529 - Note: "APIPA" is Microsoft's term. Other vendors and open source products use the term"link local" instead.
CompTIA wants us to use the APIPA term.

comments.content: IPv6 Link local address will look like this - fe80::/10.

Kind of, APIPA is a type of IPv4 Link Local address that is only given when there is nothing given by the DHCP. This is given by the computer randomly. Another type of Link Local is Ipv6 which is assigned to all interfaces by the MAC address regardless of whether they have a IP address from the DHCP. (As far as I understand, I was struggling with another problem and that lead me to this conclusion)

discussion.content: Aren't APIPA and link-local the same thing?
notice the host has 24gb of ram and 22 is being used
I think it really is important for VM host to have RAM capacity then rest follows like HDD storage and CPU

questions.question_text:
A developer wants to add a Windows 10 64-bit VM with the minimum system requirements to a virtual host workstation. The virtual host is running Windows
Server 2008 R2 and has 24GB of RAM, a 1TB hard drive, and a Gigabit Ethernet NIC with Cat 5e cabling. The current configuration of VMs is as follows:
✑ Windows 7 VM with 4GB RAM and 200GB HDD
✑ Linux VM with 16GB RAM and 200GB HDD
✑ Linux VM with 2GB RAM and 100GB HDD
Which of the following should the technician recommend to the developer FIRST?

choices.C: Upgrade the network cabling to Cat 6
choices.B: Install an additional NIC and configure teaming
choices.D: Increase the memory in the virtual host
choices.A: Increase the HDD in the virtual host

questions.question_text:
A user wants to add static storage to a laptop and is unable to physically take it apart.
Which of the following would be the BEST solution?

discussion.content: D. Cloud storage
I assume what he means static storage, is physically attached with the system....

Focusing on an important point of the question "static IP" I would not go with cloud storage because correct me if I'm wrong, cloud storage IP addresses are " dynamically assigned, which I also believe is 'automatic' again, I could be wrong! Now with a USB, you can assign a static address outside of the dhcp server address range, that way the dhcp server does does not detect it and the manually assigned static IP device continues continues to function as intended.

My understanding is that in cloud and network storage, the data can move from one server to the other so it is not "static". That leaves A an B but usb is better than optical drive so answer A would be the best.

Selected Answer: D
Cloud Storage
I would assume the USB storage is the correct answer because it's a plug and play with no network requirement as laptop tends to be for mobility and network access isn't guaranteed

comments.content: The question asked BEST. A lot of internet applications nowadays use Cloud storage for Data storage so this leans to letter D. Plus if you prolly network share u would need to set up a lot of stuff or need some resources rather than just send it directly to a cloud hassle free

discussion.content:
USB and optical drive you can take apart physically, so that would leave us with 
C and D
I haven't completely understood the concept of static storage but I guess Cloud storage would be the best bet here. Network sharing is still using your local drives so probably it can still be physically interfered with. Not sure about this
Typo .. Eable

comments.content: I was wondering how can it be USB

I think so too, because the routers will act as an access point if the "bridging" process occurs and making the highest internet speed available rather than using them individually as separate devices that gives out IP addresses in your network.

discussion.content:
okay guys, after a lot of digging! and I mean a lot. from what I read shit 802.11ac uses beamforming which will then make allow it use 2.4 and 5.0 you can essentially get the 1.3Gbs or 1300 Mbs.. ill link to the article.. hope this helps..

https://www.soundandvision.com/node/100293
im almost certain the bridge can only perform as fast as the slowest speed, even if fast networks are in the bridge... B
https://kb.netgear.com/24105/What-is-wireless-bridge-mode-and-how-do-I-set-it-up-on-my-NETGEAR-router

The Official CompTIA® A+® Core 1 and Core 2 Student Guide (Exams 220-1001 and 220-1002) | 511 - Access Points can also be configured to forward frames between one another, functioning in a Wireless Distribution System (WDS) to extend the network without
using a cabled backbone. A WDS can be configured in bridge mode, where the access points only forward communications between one another, and repeater mode, where
they also communicate with stations. A WDS can be complex to set up and can suffer from compatibility problems when devices from multiple vendors are used.
That means WAPs transfer data using the highest speed possible as all WAPs should be the same model using the same 802 standard.
No matter what 802.11s you have in a network, the network drags down to the smallest in the network. therefore, the answer is B, 54 mb. I have read about this in Proffessor messer's notes

Surprisingly, it is not B which would be the lowest common denominator in terms of speed. I believe the idea is that the slower router technologies are placed in bridge mode (making them moot essentially) while leveraging the fastest router which is AC at 1300 Mbs. Someone check me on this before I send a hitman to CompTIA for engaging in trickery rather than practical knowledge.
I think the correct answer is B

questions.question_text: Which of the following speeds would a wireless network perform at when the network is built in bridge mode containing 802.11g, 802.11n, and 802.11ac access points?
